scenario: You get an email titled 'You won Php 1,000,000' with a link and no sender name.
feedback_correct: Nice. That looks like a prize scam.
feedback_incorrect: Careful. Prize emails are usually scams. Do not click unknown links.

scenario: A friend sends a photo via a social app. The message is just a link with no caption.
choices: Ask friend if they sent it
feedback_correct: Good call. Verify before opening unknown links.
feedback_incorrect: That link could be malicious. Ask the sender first.

scenario: A website asks for your password in a popup while you are logged in.
choices: Close popup and log in from the site page
feedback_correct: Right. Legit sites do not re-request passwords in random popups.
feedback_incorrect: Popups asking for passwords can be phishing. Always use the official login page.

scenario: Someone you do not know asks to be your friend and wants personal details.
feedback_correct: Good boundary. Share only with trusted people.
feedback_incorrect: Giving personal details to strangers is risky. Keep info private.

scenario: Your browser warns a site is not secure when you try to enter card details.
feedback_correct: Correct. Only enter payment info on secure sites.
feedback_incorrect: If the site is not secure your details could be stolen.

scenario: A file named 'exam_answers.exe' appears in your downloads unexpectedly.
feedback_correct: Right. Unknown executables are often malware.
feedback_incorrect: Running unknown files can infect your device.

scenario: A pop-up offers a free prize if you fill a form and give your phone number.
feedback_correct: Good. Offers that ask for personal contact often collect data.
feedback_incorrect: Giving your number to random forms can lead to spam or scams.

scenario: Your password is 'password123' for multiple sites.
feedback_correct: Nice. Unique passwords protect you if one site is breached.
feedback_incorrect: Reusing weak passwords makes many accounts vulnerable.

scenario: An app requests access to your contacts but does not need them.
feedback_correct: Correct. Only allow permissions apps actually need.
feedback_incorrect: Unnecessary permissions can leak friend data.

scenario: A download prompt says 'This update is required' but not from the official site.
feedback_correct: Right. Always get updates from official sources.
feedback_incorrect: Fake updaters are a common way to install malware.

scenario: A shortened link in a public post claims urgent news.
feedback_correct: Good. Short links hide destinations. Verify with reliable sources.
feedback_incorrect: Short links can lead to harmful sites. Verify claims first.

scenario: Your friend asks for your game account password because they 'forgot theirs'.
choices: Tell them to use account recovery
feedback_correct: Right. Never share account passwords.
feedback_incorrect: Sharing passwords can let others take over your account.

scenario: A website shows popups and blinking ads asking you to click to continue.
feedback_correct: Good. Aggressive popups are often malicious.
feedback_incorrect: Clicking ads can download unwanted software.

scenario: You get an SMS with a code you did not request.
feedback_correct: Good. Unexpected codes can be account takeover attempts.
feedback_incorrect: Sharing codes can let attackers access your accounts.

scenario: You plug into a public charging kiosk that asks to allow data transfer.
choices: Only charge or use your own cable
feedback_correct: Correct. Public chargers can be used to steal data.
feedback_incorrect: Allowing data transfer risks exposing your phone files.

scenario: A contact sends a shortened URL with a note 'Quick, look!'.
choices: Ask why and check with contact
feedback_correct: Nice. Urgency is a common social engineering tactic.
feedback_incorrect: Attackers use urgency to make you act without thinking.

scenario: A browser extension promises free features but asks for full site access.
feedback_correct: Good. Extensions with broad access can read your data.
feedback_incorrect: Granting full access risks your privacy.

scenario: A message from your bank has spelling errors and a link to update info.
feedback_correct: Correct. Banks rarely send poorly written messages.
feedback_incorrect: Phishing often includes errors and fake links.

scenario: A software installer offers extra toolbars as optional checkboxes.
feedback_correct: Right. Decline extras you do not need.
feedback_incorrect: Extra toolbars can change settings and collect data.

scenario: Your device is slower after installing a free app from a sketchy site.
feedback_correct: Good. Performance drops can be malware.
feedback_incorrect: Suspicious apps can harm your device and data.

scenario: You receive an email from your teacher with an attached exam file. The email greeting uses your full name but the sender address has an extra letter.
choices: Confirm sender by contacting teacher in class or by school portal
feedback_correct: Smart. A small typo in email can mean a fake sender. Verify with a trusted channel.
feedback_incorrect: The address could be spoofed. Verify before opening attachments.

scenario: A colleague asks you to share a link to a cloud folder. The folder requests you to 'log in with Google' using a popup.
choices: Open a new tab and navigate to Google to check access
feedback_correct: Right. OAuth popups can be fake. Always verify the original site.
feedback_incorrect: Fake login popups can steal your credentials.

scenario: A popular app asks for SMS permissions to 'enhance messaging features' but you use a different messaging app.
feedback_correct: Good. Only allow permissions relevant to the app function.
feedback_incorrect: Extra permissions can leak private messages.

scenario: An account that looks like your friend sends a link to a 'fun quiz' but the profile photo is slightly different.
choices: Ask friend in person if they sent it
feedback_correct: Right. Impersonation is common. Confirm identity if anything feels off.
feedback_incorrect: Clicking could lead to credential theft.

scenario: Your school portal shows a notification to install a new security plugin. The download link is not from the official domain.
choices: Contact IT and get the plugin from the official site
feedback_correct: Good. Official downloads should come from official domains.
feedback_incorrect: Installing unofficial plugins can compromise the system.

scenario: A website login asks you to verify your account by entering the last 4 digits of another service.
choices: Use official account recovery methods or contact support
feedback_correct: Correct. Sites should not request unrelated account details.
feedback_incorrect: Sharing parts of other accounts can help attackers piece together access.

scenario: You are offered a free wireless network at a cafe called 'FreeCafeWiFi' and another labeled 'FreeCafeWiFi_secure'.
choices: Ask staff for the official network name
feedback_correct: Smart. Some networks spoof real names to intercept traffic. Ask staff.
feedback_incorrect: Connecting to fake networks can allow attackers to monitor your traffic.

scenario: A friend sends a file but the file extension is double, like 'photo.jpg.exe'.
choices: Refuse and ask for correct file format
feedback_correct: Good. Double extensions are a sign of executable malware disguised as media.
feedback_incorrect: Opening such files can execute malware.

scenario: A web article links to a 'required document' but the download is hosted on a general file sharing site with many files.
choices: Ask the author for the direct official source
feedback_correct: Good. Files on general hosting can be replaced or faked. Ask the author.
feedback_incorrect: Downloads from unknown hosting can be unsafe.

scenario: You receive a message from an old classmate asking for a money transfer to help with an emergency. The account name is slightly different.
choices: Call or message the classmate using a known number to confirm
feedback_correct: Right. Emergency money requests are common scams. Confirm with reliable contact methods.
feedback_incorrect: Scammers often create urgency to trick you into sending money.

scenario: A browser says a certificate is invalid on a site where you usually log in to check grades.
choices: Use the school portal link you know or contact IT
feedback_correct: Good. Certificate warnings mean the connection may not be secure. Confirm before proceeding.
feedback_incorrect: Ignoring certificate warnings risks exposing your credentials.

scenario: An app update is available in an unofficial app marketplace but not in the official store.
feedback_correct: Correct. Unofficial stores may host altered or malicious apps.
feedback_incorrect: Installing from unknown marketplaces can be dangerous.

scenario: Your social media account shows a login from a location you do not recognize. A message asks you to confirm and click a link.
choices: Log in via the official site or app and check security settings
feedback_correct: Right. Use official channels to manage account security.
feedback_incorrect: Clicking suspicious links can lead to account compromise.

scenario: A site asks you to sign in with your school account but the sign-in screen URL is long and includes many redirects.
choices: Confirm the URL and use trusted sign-in flow
feedback_correct: Good. Complex redirect URLs can hide malicious redirects.
feedback_incorrect: Redirects can route your credentials to attackers.

scenario: A message claims a friend sent you money with a screenshot but the transaction ID is missing.
choices: Verify payment through the official payment app or ask friend to confirm
feedback_correct: Smart. Screenshots can be edited. Verify through official transaction records.
feedback_incorrect: Screenshots alone are not proof of payment.

scenario: A free utility asks you to disable your antivirus for installation to 'work properly'.
choices: Cancel installation and find a trusted source
feedback_correct: Good. Legit software rarely needs permanent antivirus disablement.
feedback_incorrect: Disabling antivirus can expose your system to threats.

scenario: An online form asks for your full birth date and mother's maiden name to 'verify identity' before you can read a public article.
choices: Use alternate verification like creating an account with minimal info or find another source
feedback_correct: Good. Sensitive personal data should not be requested for casual access.
feedback_incorrect: Sharing personal identifiers can help attackers impersonate you.

scenario: A friend asks you to join a group call and provides a link. The link opens an unknown app that requests camera access immediately.
choices: Ask what app it is and whether others recommend it
feedback_correct: Right. Confirm the app before granting camera or microphone access.
feedback_incorrect: Granting access to unknown apps can compromise your privacy.

scenario: A new job listing asks for copies of your ID before any interview.
choices: Ask for an interview first and verify the employer
feedback_correct: Smart. Employers normally verify identity later and through official channels.
feedback_incorrect: Sending ID early can risk identity theft.

scenario: You receive a link to download a PDF. Your device warns the file type might be unsafe because it is actually an executable.
choices: Do not open and ask sender for the correct format
feedback_correct: Good. Executables disguised as PDFs are malicious.
feedback_incorrect: Opening disguised files can run malicious code.

scenario: A recruiter contacts you with a job offer but asks you to upload a scan of your ID to a third-party website not linked to the company.
choices: Ask for official HR contact and confirm process
feedback_correct: Good. Identity documents should only be shared through verified company channels.
feedback_incorrect: Uploading IDs to unknown sites risks identity theft.

scenario: A message appears that looks exactly like your school portal, but the URL has 'school-verify.com' instead of the official domain.
choices: Close page and access only from official link
feedback_correct: Right. Fake portals use lookalike domains to steal logins.
feedback_incorrect: Entering details here would give attackers your credentials.

scenario: An email from your bank arrives with your name correctly spelled and professional branding. The link in the email has a correct logo but the address is different.
choices: Log in by typing the official bank URL manually
feedback_correct: Correct. Even well-made phishing emails can hide fake links.
feedback_incorrect: Logos and branding can be copied. Only trust official URLs.

scenario: A free online tool offers to combine multiple PDFs but requires you to sign in with your email and password instead of Google or school SSO.
choices: Use a tool that does not request credentials
feedback_correct: Good. No tool should ask for your email account password directly.
feedback_incorrect: Sharing your email password exposes your entire account.

scenario: Your device shows a system update notification. When you click it, it opens a browser page instead of the settings menu.
choices: Cancel and update only via system settings
feedback_correct: Smart. Updates should come from device settings, not random web pages.
feedback_incorrect: Fake update prompts can install malware.

scenario: A scholarship website requires you to upload a copy of your transcript and asks for your login to the student portal as 'verification'.
choices: Submit only the transcript and confirm with school
feedback_correct: Correct. Real scholarships never request your portal credentials.
feedback_incorrect: Sharing credentials hands over full access to attackers.

scenario: A new social platform promises early access if you log in using your email and password, not OAuth providers.
choices: Skip and wait for official access methods
feedback_correct: Right. Apps should not demand your email password directly.
feedback_incorrect: Giving passwords to third-party apps is unsafe.

scenario: An email contains a correct-looking invoice PDF. When opened, it asks you to enable macros to see the content.
choices: Do not enable and verify with the sender first
feedback_correct: Good. Macros in unexpected files often hide malware.
feedback_incorrect: Enabling macros can let malicious code run.

scenario: A cloud storage share link looks correct but uses http:// instead of https://.
feedback_correct: Correct. Secure connections use HTTPS to protect data.
feedback_incorrect: HTTP links are vulnerable to interception.

scenario: An online contest asks for your student number, password, and home address to 'register'.
choices: Do not register with sensitive info
feedback_correct: Good. Contests should not request login details and sensitive data.
feedback_incorrect: This is likely a scam to collect your personal info.

scenario: A free VPN app requests device admin privileges before letting you connect.
feedback_correct: Right. Legit VPNs do not require full admin control.
feedback_incorrect: Granting admin rights lets apps fully control your device.

scenario: You are invited to a video conference. The link looks valid but the certificate is self-signed and not from the provider.
choices: Decline and verify invite with host
feedback_correct: Correct. Certificates prove authenticity. Self-signed ones are risky.
feedback_incorrect: Joining with invalid certificates risks exposure.

scenario: You download an academic paper but the file asks you to install a viewer before opening.
feedback_correct: Good. PDFs should open in trusted software.
feedback_incorrect: Extra viewers may contain malware.

scenario: A browser extension offers to auto-fill forms but requires access to all your passwords.
feedback_correct: Right. Auto-fill extensions should not require your stored passwords.
feedback_incorrect: This could steal your saved credentials.

scenario: A mobile banking app update appears in an ad banner on a website.
choices: Update only via official app store
feedback_correct: Smart. Updates should only come through official app stores.
feedback_incorrect: Ad-based downloads are unsafe and often fake.

scenario: You receive a calendar invite with a suspicious link attached to the event details.
feedback_correct: Good. Event invites can be abused to spread links.
feedback_incorrect: Clicking invites may lead to phishing sites.

scenario: An online payment processor requests your credit card PIN along with number and CVV.
choices: Decline and use trusted payment gateway
feedback_correct: Right. No service should ask for your card PIN.
feedback_incorrect: Sharing your PIN compromises your bank account.

scenario: You see a login page that looks correct but it loads over an IP address instead of a domain name.
feedback_correct: Correct. Legit sites use domain names with certificates.
feedback_incorrect: IP-only login pages are often phishing.

scenario: A study resource site offers free premium accounts if you download a helper app first.
feedback_correct: Good. Free premium access is a bait for malware installs.
feedback_incorrect: Downloading helper apps risks infecting your device.

scenario: You get an email that includes your old leaked password in the subject line and demands payment to keep your data private.
feedback_correct: Smart. This is a scare tactic using leaked data. Change your credentials instead.
feedback_incorrect: Paying encourages attackers. Always reset your passwords.
